Line 44: Line 44:
The calcium carbonate layers in a shell are generally of two types: an outer, chalk-like prismatic layer and an inner pearly, lamellar or nacreous layer. The layers usually incorporate a substance called [[conchiolin]], often in order to help bind the calcium carbonate crystals together. Conchiolin is composed largely of [[quinone]]-tanned [[protein]]s.
The calcium carbonate layers in a shell are generally of two types: an outer, chalk-like prismatic layer and an inner pearly, lamellar or nacreous layer. The layers usually incorporate a substance called [[conchiolin]], often in order to help bind the calcium carbonate crystals together. Conchiolin is composed largely of [[quinone]]-tanned [[protein]]s.
â
The periostracum and prismatic layer are secreted by a marginal band of cells, so that the shell grows at its outer edge. Conversely, the nacreous layer is derived from the main surface of the mantle.<ref>"integument (mollusks)."EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica. 2009. EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica 2006 Ultimate Reference Suite DVD</ref>
+
The periostracum and prismatic layer are secreted by a marginal band of cells, so that the shell grows at its outer edge. Conversely, the nacreous layer is derived from the main surface of the mantle.<ref>"integument (mollusks)."EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica. 2009. [[EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica 2006 Ultimate Reference Suite DVD]]</ref>
Some shells contain pigments which are incorporated into the structure. This is what accounts for the striking colors and patterns that can be seen in some species of [[seashell]]s, and the shells of some tropical land snails. These shell pigments sometimes include compounds such as [[pyrrole]]s and [[porphyrin]]s.

This is what accounts for the striking colors and patterns that can be seen in some species of [[seashell]]s, and the shells of some tropical land snails.
